musicalLanguage.description: The opening track from Kind of Blue — the best-selling jazz album in history. Built on just two scales (D dorian and Eb dorian), So What is the gateway to modal jazz. The famous two-chord piano voicing (stacked fourths answered by bass) defines the sound.
musicalLanguage.structure: AABA — 32 bars. This excerpt: first A section (8 bars in D dorian)
keyMoments: Bar 1-2: The iconic bass call — ascending answer from the piano in quartal voicings
Bar 3-4: Melody floats over D dorian with cool detachment
Bar 7-8: Phrase resolves gently — space and silence are part of the music
teachingGoals: Quartal voicings — chords built in fourths instead of thirds
D dorian mode — D E F G A B C D — the 'jazz minor' sound
Less is more — Miles played fewer notes, not more
styleTips: Leave space — the rests are as important as the notes
The quartal voicing is E-A-D-G-B, not a traditional Dm chord
Swing lightly — this is cool jazz, not hard bop. Stay relaxed.

measures.teachingNote: Bass establishes D. Right hand enters on beat 3 — the classic 'call' gesture.
The quartal 'answer' voicing — E-A-D-G stacked in fourths. Let it ring.
Melody descends through D dorian. Simple, vocal, space between phrases.
Melody moves stepwise. Every note is a chord tone of D dorian.
A4 sustains, then silence, then D5 — Miles-style phrasing with breath.
Descending line from E5. Keep it smooth and connected.
Two half notes — simplicity. The G resolves up to A, the dorian fifth.
Rest on the tonic. Let the sound decay naturally. This is where the next section would begin.
